comment.narrative: 1.1 .UNDP has provided support to the Ministry of Social Development (MSD) in preparing the National Action Plan on Gender Equality 2015-2017 according the National Strategy for Gender Equality (2012-2020). 1.2.UNDP has supported the Ministry of Internal Affairs in development the National Action Plan on UN SC Resolution #1325 1.3.UNDP contributed to building capacity of national partners on implementation of international and national gender equality commitments: MSD Gender Policy Department Head and Board Member of Association of Women Police Officers participated in Regional Conference on Effective Programming for Enhancing Women’s Security and Access to Justice, Including Preventing and Combating Sexual Gender- Based Violence. 2. Gender equality objectives have been reflected in UNDP programme AWPs. UNDP Kyrgyzstan has increased the resources allocated for gender mainstreaming activities (about 20% from overall budget), including two projects marked by Gender Marker 3. 3. 95% of staff completed the online gender mainstreaming courses. Country Office Gender Focal Point and Country Programme Gender Coordinator’s capacities strengthened through participating at ITC-ILO Gender Academy and by participating UNDP Regional Conference on Effective Programming for Enhancing Women’s Security and Access to Justice, Including Preventing and Combating Sexual Gender- Based Violence. 4. Successfully partnered with UN Women, UNODC, OSCE on substantive joint project initiatives – support to the National Women's Forum of the Kyrgyz Republic, initiated by International Public Foundation “Initiative of Roza Otunbayeva”; UN Women, NDI, IRI, OSCE – support to the International Conference “Parliament Role in Advancing Gender Equality in context of Bejing+20”; ACTED - EXTENDED CONSULTATIVE MEETING of interagency working group members on the development of National action plan on implementation of UN SCR № 1325 for 2015-2017 with the civil society representatives; UN Women, Friedr

comment.narrative: 1. Designing the Package of legal regulations and normative acts for development and use of small hydropower and RES; the draft of the methodology of Tariff for SHPs, RES and Purchaing Power Agreement. 2. Development the capacity and the package of legal regulations, normative acts for stimulating investors and promotion the exploitation of small hydropower; promotion the nationally appropriate mitigation actions for Small Hydropower. 3. 1. New package of legal regulations and normative acts to amend certain acts of KR (Land and Water Codes and the Laws of KR: On natural monopoly in KR, On state statistics, On National Academy of Science of KR) in accordance with the Law "On renewable energy sources" is approved by the Governmental Decree N501 as of 15 June 2015 and was submitted to the Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic for final review and approval. Draft Concept of development of small hydropower in the Kyrgyz Republic for 2015-2017 is approved by the Governmental Decree N505 as of 20 June 2015.
Following creation of the independent regulator in the fuel and energy complex, the State Agency for Fuel and Energy Complex Regulation, the work on methodology for calculating small hydropower tariffs has been finalized. The Methodology is adopted by the State Agency for Fuel and Energy Complex Regulation’s Order N1 as of 6 August 2015.
Draft standard PPA has been developed, reviewed by the Ministry of Energy and Industry, received approval from energy companies (developers) and is submitted to the Government for final approval.
2. Package of legal regulations and normative acts to promote effective exploitation of RES, including Regulation on land tenure procedure, Regulation on water use agreements and Rules on technological connection to the power grid and assessment methodology for calculation of fee on technological connection are developed, passed the public debate and submitted to the Government for final approval.
Draft Concession agreement is adopted by the Ministry of Energy and Industry of KR and submitted to the Government for final approval.
3. Czech Trust Fund funding has been allocated for 6 experts from the Ministry of Energy and Industry, State Agency for Regulation of Energy, Government, acting small hydroelectric power and civil society for a capacity building tour in the Czech Republic. Study tour for those 6 experts from Kyrgyzstan has been organized in July 2015. Experts were a

At least 3 drafts of bylaws within implementation of the Law “On Provision of Public and Municipal Services” developed and submitted to the Prime-minister Office.

Output 1. Result: 3 drafts Government Decrees developed for the effective and timely implementation of the Law “On Provision of Public and Municipal Services”. These legal acts (the Law and Government Decrees) are a key step in area of improving of public administration reform, where questions of public services are being essential and primarily for society. These normative legal acts directly concerns the entire population, and aims to ensure the quality and accessibility of services for the citizen.
Output 2. Output 1: 1. # of conflict prevention-related laws/ strategies/ plans/ policies drafted, amended, passed or implemented (# of which promote gender equality). 2.1.# of stakeholders trained and capable to apply MPR-D methodology. 2.2. # of scenario cases developed and discussed. 3. # of dialogue platforms conducted and # of preventivemeasures/ actions taken following these platforms (# of measures that promote gender equality issues and increasing the role of women in peacebuilding). 4. # of mediation and dialogue pilots implemented and documented.
Output 2: 1. # of local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations able to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation (# of women leaders in the trainings and # of preventive actions undertaken by women. 2. # of capacity building interventions conducted for Advisory Committees that have led to concrete positive changes in their work (# of interventions with tangible benefit for the role of women in peacebuilding). 3. # of new collaborations/ initiatives kick-started in the area of conflict monitoring and preventive action based on networking efforts. 4. # of documented cases in which ICT for conflict prevention was used in the context of monitoring and preventive action. 5. # of women initiatives contributing to confidence- and peacebuilding.
Output 3: 1. # of recommendations of risk assessment accepted by border security and considered for future planning. 2. # of consultations/ negotiations supported towards reaching agreement on possible cross-border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

comment.narrative:
Output 1: 1. National Institutions have limited capacities to design and implement conflict prevention policies. Governmental officials were not aware on conflict sensitivity, gender aspects, and had no enough skills to develop policy. 2. Government doesn’t use methodology to manage political risks for development. 3. Prior to International Conference on conflict sensitive law-making there was no dialogue between civil society and authorities. There is lack of collaboration between Oblast-level officials and civil society on one side and state decisions makers on the other to jointly monitor tensions and take early preventive action (including mediation). 4. Lack of support to mentor and coach real mediation processes or mediation practice support.
Output 2: 1. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations have limited ability to monitor and respond to potential conflict escalation. 2. Advisory Committees have limited capacities to initiate conflict prevention and peace building interventions. 3. Local NGOs, advisory committees, women and youth organizations do not sufficiently coordinate their efforts. 4. ICT review has identified lack of support for ICT development in peace building. 5.Lack of support to women driven initiatives in peace building.
Output 3: 1. Limited capacities to assess potential conflict risks related to border security. 2. Lack of cross border cooperation between Kyrgyzstan and Uzbekistan.

Target #1. At least 3 recommendations from the assessment were taken up and implemented by development partners, civil society and/or national stakeholders Target #2. Dialogues carried out and collaborations facilitated have been covered at least 8 times by the media Target #3. At least 5 incidents were tracked and responded to (documentation of cases with reflection on their outcomes) Target #4. At least 3 conflict sensitive activities of youth/women empowerment action plans supported

Electoral Risk Management Tool (ERM) offered free-of-charge by IDEA (Sweden) to National Institute for Strategic Studies (NISS) has been adjusted and launched after baseline electoral risk assessment. 10 weekly reports on possible electoral risks have been prepared and discussed during inter-agency coordination workshops engaging law enforcement structures, Central Electoral Committee and relevant Government bodies including security services and Defense Council. Local authorities jointly with community leaders from both sides of the border addressed 3 critical issues (based on incident reports produced by local monitors) related to re-construction of local market (adding additional trading spaces for Tajik residents), moving mobile border post on the strategic road Ovchu Kalacha-Beshkent, which posed difficulties for internal movement of Kyrgyz residents and advanced negotiations between local authorities on joint re-habilitation of the shared road. Moreover monitoring reports laid the ground for negotiations of other 12 projects aimed at improving cross border relations. Most of projects related to rehabilitation or construction of water infrastructure and required extensive consultations between different government and non-government bodies due to sensitivity of the cases (located on disputed territories where border demarcation and delimitation has not finalized yet). UNDP supported 16 day campaign to prevent violence against women and girls with active involvement of local media resources, supported Karakol Mayor’s office to launch participatory process of drafting youth empowerment action plan, assisted Kok-Oy LSG to reduce conflict potential with involvement of youth through youth empowerment activities.

Target #1. 10% increase of constructive participation of young women and menin decision making porcesses at all levels Target #2: 10% increase in vulnerable young women and men that are optimistic about their future Target #3. at least 13 development strategies and policies with inclusion of budgetary stipulation addressing needs and priorities of young men and women at the local and national levels

Compared with previous years, there is significant decrease in the level of tensions and conflicts among young people. Thus 4 deconstructive youth behavior was recorded this year against 44 registered earlier. In some communities with no prior youth project experience UN is seen by young people as a unique opportunity for development and gives them an incentive for positive change. UNDP through its activities empowered around 3000 (61%) young people from different ethnic groups to become local activists and leaders of youth-led projects in their communities who can promote various youth initiatives in close partnership with LSGs. Thus 11 out of 14 LSGs developed youth empowerment action plans supported by local budgets.

description.narrative: Strengthening capacities of Local Self Governance (LSGs) for peacebuilding

Number of violent disputes decreases within targeted LSGs
Percentage of existing LSG-led local grievance resolution mechanisms and decision-making bodies in targeted communities that include under-represented groups

comment.narrative: To be identified in the inception phase

Target #1. At least 5 % increase in number of cases relating to conflicts that LSGs targeted in the project have addressed with support of the Agency for LSG Affairs and Interethnic Relations and their affiliated structures (with breakdown of how many of those were resolved) Target #2. At least 10 % increase in number of joint initiatives carried out by the Agency for LSG Affairs and Interethnic Relations in collaboration with other state bodies and /or civil society to increase the percentage of under-represented groups in LSG-led local grievance resolution mechanisms and decision-making bodies (breakdown of how many of those were successful, e.g. because they resulted in policy changes, actual increase in representation etc.) Target #3. At least 5 % increase in % of women in LSG-led local grievance resolution mechanisms and decision-making bodies Target #4. Action plan to national religious policy drafted and operationalized

Out of 108 conflicts registered in 2014 GAMSUMO intervened in 21 cases. Thus the average percentage of GAMSUMO cooperation with LSGs in resolving local conflicts comprise above 19%. Monitoring Centre under the Government Agency for LSG and Interethnic Relations (GAMSUMO) prepared 20 analytical notes, 8 full reports and 2 baseline surveys on the most critical topics identified by Office of President and GAMSUMO. Moreover overall facts and findings from monitoring reports form the basis for conflict mapping software which has visualized potential hot spots geographically. Capacities of the Agency and 20 district level public reception centres of GAMSUMO were built in grant management tailored for conflict prevention and peace-building needs. Public reception centers have been linked to 14 multi-stakeholder Local Development Committees (which include under-represented groups) which have drafted and implemented 35 local development projects based on action plans prepared in 2014 as a result of participatory conflict analysis. 20 local projects supported through local budgets after being discussed and approved at the sessions of Local Councils. In general the level of women participation in peace-building processes at the local level including women working in executive LSG bodies (in fact decision making bodies) comprise around 41%. To implement gender responsive local action plans LSGs supported 8 out of 35 local projects which directly address women needs and women's engagement in protest actions and conflicts including 2 Gender Centers.

comment.narrative: 1. 2000 people (40% are women) improved skills on business and agriculture development 2. At least 300 beneficiaries (with special focus on women and youth) received access to soft loans through Revolving Fund 3. 50 SMEs, including women-lead established 4. Not less than 10 000 people (50% are women) received access to potable and irrigation water 5. 30 % of unemployed people have an access to new workplaces due to the mechanisms improved and conditions created for market-driven specialties 6. Not less than 200 jobs (for men and women) created 7. Not less than 20 000 people (40% are women) received access to improved rural infrastructure 8. 120 household income increased by 30% 9. 1. 315 beneficiaries (29% or 92 are women) improved their business and entrepreneurial skills, as well as skills in agriculture development. 32 teachers and masters (42% or 13 are women) of target vocational schools upgraded their professional skills on specialized courses. 2. 253 beneficiaries (55% or 139 are women) received microloans from the Revolving Fund for initiating and developing their income-generating activities 3. 52 small enterprises in the area of service provision, as well as production and processing of agricultural products are established 4. 11 thousand people (52% or 5720 are women) benefit from improved access to potable water. Irrigation of 5907 hectares of arable lands owned by 3068 households is improved 5. 392 people are trained on such majors as Cook, Needlewoman, and Gas and electric welder. 201 graduates (51%) are employed 6. 211 new jobs are created. 78 or 37% of jobs are created for women 7. 35275 people (9000 households, 17903 or 51% are women) benefit from access to improved infrastructure in their villages (electricity supply, village roads, street lights and others) 8. Members of 380 households from 12 pilot villages increased their income by 50% 9. 180 rural women improved their knowledge and skills in developing business in the area of dairy production, pastry production, and greenhouse farming 10. Based on improved skills and knowledge through support of the project, 12 new veterinary service points provide high quality services, take systematic preventive measures and provide treatment to livestock. 144 members of self-help groups from 6 pilot villages increased their household income through support of the project in development of sheep breeding and provision of forage

comment.narrative: 2014 B1: Lack of support to women driven initiatives in peace building B2: 70% of local community is not provided by potable water supply B3: Management capacities and tools as well as financial sustainability of decentralized rural DWSS systems operators are rather limited B4: Poor sanitation and hygiene conditions B5: Majority of youth in rural areas employed in the agricultural sector B6: 52 % of youth are economically active B7: Women are not interested/don’t lead businesses B8: 60% of local community is under natural disaster risk B9: Low level of awareness on disaster risk management principles

T1:At least 60% of the pilot local community has access to drinking water and improved sanitary and hygiene conditions T2:At least 80% of pilot local community is aware of good sanitation and hygiene (gender and age disaggregated) T3:At least one local development plan addressing DWSS issues T4:At least 100 parents trained (gender disaggregated) and water consumers (gender disaggregated) on sanitation and hygiene principles T5:At least 60% of community inhabitants are satisfied with water association capacity T6:At least 120 local residents have improved their skills in water management and consumption (60 % -women) T7:At least one Local development plan of pilot community included climate change adaption issues T8:At least 10 % of pilot community population have an access to effective agriculture and water resources policies within climate change adaptation T9:Disaster response capacity of LSGs & communities strengthened T10:Disaster risks mitigated in pilot LSGs through implementation of income-generating, conflict sensitive and climate resilient projects (at least one project) T11:One toolkit developed and agreed with national partners to sustain and replicate climate risk management approaches in local level T12:Legal and methodological framework for strategic planning oriented to sustainable development is consolidated. T13:PEI programme interventions reflect gender mainstreaming at all levels (at least three activities are carried out with a full focus on gender aspects).

R1: 5 954 households with the population of 35 815 people (women – 18975) have an access to potable water; increased their sanitation and hygiene R2: 2200 people (1320 are women) from three villages of Jekendi LSG were trained on such issues as identify main issues on sanitation and hygiene, future collaboration between the LSG, Village Health Committee and School Health Committee in the dissemination health messages. 250 posters on good sanitation and hygiene practices were given for school students, people of Karamyk village . Project team organized the mass public events "Clean Street and clean House", "Clean water - source of health" with the participation of 250 students, representatives of the Jekendi LSG, teachers (120 are women), launched an essay competition focusing on best sanitation and hygiene practices among schools in Jekendi LSG, selected the best essays for practice use. R3: The drink water sanitation system issues included in the Local development plan of Jekendi pilot community. 177 community members willing to support the Local development plan of installation of the water pipe. It was agreed to create five groups of 32 people and to appoint one representative for each group. R4: 172 parents (171 are women) from three villages of Jekendi LSG were trained on basics of sanitation and hygiene, on personal hygiene, drinking water safety. R 5: 177 members (92- women) of Rural Public Association of Drinking Water Consumers received access to the information on water supply management through trainings, seminars, round tables and study-tours; R6: 276 members (109- women) of Association of Water Consumers received access to the information on water supply management through trainings, seminars, round tables and study-tours. 3 Association of Water Consumers unifying 5835 potable water consumers, were provided with construction materials in an amount of 533463 KGS to improve irrigation water supply system in 3 villages of Kosh-Dobo LSG, Ylai-Talaa LS

description.narrative: Local government and communities in selected geographical areas better address complex development problems using ABD approach.
independent political entity

Output V. Cross-border communities along the Tajik-Kyrgyz border establish/ strengthen mechanisms for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving.
Indicators: Number of documented case studies from cross-border village clusters that demonstrate how mechanisms for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving helped to reduce local tensions and promoted cross-border cooperation Number of agreements reached (or project ideas identified) between cross-border communities % of women taking part in cross-border and intercommunity dialogue. # of youth engaged into vocational education and business skills trainings. # of youth received covered by UNDP activities to increase # of income generation sources. # of sustainable business ideas generated as a result of capacity building. # of business projects funded through small grants. # of employed after completion of vocational education courses

comment.narrative: Baseline: Following the recent violent incidents along the Tajik border, spaces for dialogue, deliberation, and joint problem-solving have diminished; Key local institutions on both sides of the border are able to design and implement conflict prevention policies, and manage risks to stability Mechanisms for dialogue, joint problem-solving and cooperation are in place to reduce tensions in cross-border areas. Youth comprise 51 % of “supply” in the labor market. 62 % of youth are economically active. Youth employment rate is 56%. Majority of youth in rural areas employed in the agricultural sector.

1. Mechaisms for joint problem solving is created in pilot communities. Project sides jointly identified and implemented; % of women taking part in cross border intercommunity dialogue has increased. 2. To strengthen resilience of local communities through applying integrated DRR approach. At least 3 local self-governments supported by appropriate toolkits & consultancy to strengthen their capacity in integrated DRR for further scaling up of best practices. 3. To expand opportunities for income generation and employment among vulnerable groups with the focus on environmental security and gender equality. Women consist at least 30% of beneficieares of the project activities.

1. In cooperation with UNDP Tajikistan 4 pilot cluster most prone to conflicts are identified. 5 conflict monitors on both sides of the border are hired to trace the situation in most problematic areas in different fields (water resource, natural resource, border management, economic relations etc.). As a result of cross border dialogue between residents of border communities 12 infrastructure projects aimed at conflict reduction, trust inrease, development of cross border trade were identified. At least 30% of projects participants are women. Total amount of projects made up 7746725 KGS, out of them UNDP interventions are 6017552 KGS and community contribution is 1729173 KGS. Following were achieved upon projects implementation: Improved irrigation of 600 hectares on Kyrgyz side and 300 hectares on Tajik side that will increase crop capacity and well being of local residents; 1600 people (50% are women) received improved access to drinking water; More than 1000 residents (50% women) living in cross border streets of Jany Jer AO received street lightening on solar panels. It lead to decrease of criminal rate in Jany Jer AO. More than 100 representatives (20% women) of youth generation of Arka village received improved conditions for sports activities. More than 220 trade places created at border markets of Samarkandek and Kulundu AO. 2. Three "green projects" for reducing natural disaster risks through participation of and for the benefits of poor, excluded and vulnerable groups (children, women, elderly and disabled) is developed and implemented. 3 local authorities with strengthened capacity in integrated DRR. 3. Supported initiatives of vulnerable group of people in small towns to create income generation and business development activities with emphasis on women and youth.

To be completed in 2016. 6. 4 CSOs engaged in the Coordination Council. To be completed in 2016. 7. To be completed in 2016. title.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of PAs in the Central Tian Shan Mountains project

description.narrative: Improving the coverage and management effectiveness of Protected Areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains.
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
1. Mainly activities carried out during the period were awareness raising of relevant local communities and local decision makers on protected areas for biodiversity conservation and livelihood, sustainable land resources management. 17 rural gatherings and 9 decision making meetings on establishing new PA were held. As a result 4 more local self-governance bodies take a positive decision on establishing new PA. Map of each target local self-governance with land compositions was prepared. The Project still has been negotiating with 1 local self-governance body, which is against for establishing new PA and land transformation belonging to them. Meetings, negotiations with local decision makers brought together the high level officials: members of Parliament of the Kyrgyz Republic, Plenipotentiary Representative of the Issyk-Kul region, local government representatives, government nature protection institutions to convince local decision makers that PAs establishment the most effective and proven tool for maintain the essential natural resources and services and get approval for establishing new PA.
According to the Global Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Programme that aims to identify and secure 20 landscapes across snow leopard range by year 2020, there are 23 national scale landscapes (Report of the FFI/CMS workshop Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan 1st 2nd December 2014). The Project site has been included as one of the key landscapes for show leopard conservation in the Kyrgyz Republic. 2. During this reporting period: A reported reduction is by 7.5%. no illegal poaching and illegal logging in the existing Sarychat-Eertash Reserve was recorded. In the Project site area, 38 illegal poaching cases were detected by volunteer inspectors jointly with Issyk-Kel Biosphere Territory of SAEPF rangers of total penalty amount of 2,790 USD. 3. The Project jointly with Poverty and Environment is implementing the ToR increasing awareness on gender through the prizms of po

description.narrative: To improve the coverage and effectiveness of protected areas in the Central Tian Shan Mountains so as to expand threatened species representation in the national system
Territorial coverage of SPNAs in Central Tian Shan Mountains which provide habitat for the endangered snow leopard

comment.narrative: 149,117.9 ha (Existing Sarychat Ertash reserve area)
Up to 336,119.9 ha by project end

Researchers from Biology and Soil Institute of the National Academy of Sciences of the Kyrgyz Republic have conducted the field study in the Project site.
Based on the results of the literature review and obtained data from field survey Biology and Soil Institute provided the following: (i) Information on preliminary assessment of the flora, vertebrates (mammals, birds, cold-blooded animals), (ii) summary lists of flora and fauna, locations, biota, large mammals migration routes; (iii) Preliminary assessment of sacred natural sites and cultural landscapes of the Project site; Soil types; (iv)Recommendations for new establishing “Khan-Tengri” State Nature Park zoning and ecological corridors borders.
Flora:
10 vegetation types, 457 plant species found and identified; Out of which: 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 8 endemic species which are natural to or characteristic to this place; 11 species can be found only in the Project site in the Kyrgyz Republic. In addition, 4 mosses, 122 mushrooms, 287 lichen were found.
Fauna:
100 bird species, out of which 8 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN; 13 species are listed in the CITES (appendix II).
22 mammals, out of which 5 species included in the Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; 4 species included in the Red List of the IUCN; 4 species are listed in the CITES (appendix II, I).
Staff of the State Agency on Environment Protection and Forestry completed a feasibility study for establishing a new PA. The socio-economic impact of the new PA was identified including: (i) socio-economic status, population growth, and land use composition measures; (ii) current use of the Project site land for agricultural and industry use and future prospect; (iii) water and mineral resources and their long-term perspective; (iv) modern use of forest and game species in the Project site and prospects; (v) anthropogenic pressures and threats to landscape, nature resources.
Based on the results of the feasibility study and ecological assessment, tentatively, an area of 325,785 ha for the new park was identified, which has the potential to ensure conservation of mountain fragile ecosystems including flora and fauna along with sustainable development for local people residing around the Park. Out of 325,785 ha, 226,888.2 ha were identified for the core zone of the Park; 17,808 ha – ecological stabilization zone for restoration and conservation activities; 8,323.4 ha - for tourism & recreational zone; 72,765.5 ha zone for limited economic activities, where traditional farming practices and biodiversity friendly activities are allowed. A social survey was held among local people to be impacted by the park creation, i.e. their lands will be transferred to “Protected areas” category. The survey involved 1,383 households, of which 75% indicated support for the establishment of the park and 17% - against its establishment.

description.narrative: Population size of snow leopard (Uncia Uncia) in Central Tian Shan shows an increasing trend

comment.narrative: Low numbers of snow leopard (unable to quantify)
By project end, target area offers permanent habitat for 5 females with cubs

During field surveys conducted by the Biology and Soil Institute, three sites in the Project area had signs of snow leopard activities. A questionnaire among local herders indicated that about 5-7 snow leopards were seen in the area. The snow leopard and its prey species’ habitat, migration routes, seasons, directions were developed.
According to the Global Snow Leopard and Ecosystem Protection Programme that aims to identify and secure 20 landscapes across snow leopard range by year 2020, there are 23 national scale landscapes (Report of the FFI/CMS workshop Bishkek, Kyrgyzstan 1st – 2nd December 2014).
The Project site has been included as one of the key landscapes for show leopard conservation in the Kyrgyz Republic.

description.narrative: Threatened species representation is improved by increasing coverage and management effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan
Enhanced management effectiveness of target PAs (as measured by METT)

comment.narrative:
Sarychat Ertash: 54%
Khan Tengri: 3%

Sarychat Ertash: 75% by project end
Khan Tengri: 28% by project end

No METT assessment has been conducted in the reporting period.
The adopted methodology on PA effectiveness assessment and METT will be used after establishing the State Nature Park “Khan-Teniri’, the establishment is under negotiation with local self-governance bodies. The updated METT scores are expected to be available for the next PIR in 2016.

description.narrative: Reduction in poaching and illegal logging at target PAs (annual) per unit of patrolling effort, compared with year of initial patrolling

comment.narrative:
Illegal logging violations: 50
Poaching violations: 70
Total violations: 120
Reduction by 30%

During this reporting period:
A reported reduction is by 7.5%.
“no” illegal poaching and illegal logging in the existing Sarychat-Eertash Reserve was recorded.
In the Project site area, 9 illegal poaching cases were detected by volunteer inspectors jointly with “Issyk-Kel” Biosphere Territory of SAEPF rangers of total penalty amount of 1,200 USD.

description.narrative: Habitat connectivity, sustainability and effectiveness of PAs in Central Tian Shan are enhanced by regulating land use in buffer zones, wildlife corridors and other intervening landscapes
Law on SPNAs provides clear guidance on establishment, management, and responsible party for PA buffer zones and wildlife corridors

comment.narrative: Current law is unclear
Legislation improved through amendments by project end

No change of the baseline indicator.
According to the Law on Protected Areas of the Kyrgyz Republic (2011) there are 4 zones in the state nature parks: core zone; ecological stabilization zone; tourist-recreational zone; zone for limited economic activities.
In accordance with SEAPF and Project board meeting suggestions (November, 2014) the above mentioned zones (except for the core zone) should be accepted as a buffer zone for the State Nature Park “Khan-Tengri”.
During the reporting period the Project has reviewed the gaps in PA legislation and policy concerning establishment of zones, its regimes and ecological corridors.
The Project initiated review of the Law of the Kyrgyz Republic on PA. By the Project support the following legislations were drafted: The Regulation on PA establishment in the Kyrgyz Republic, Regulation on Red Data Book of the Kyrgyz Republic; Regulation on land use in State Nature Parks; Regulation on Ecological corridors and proposal for making amendments to Law on PA submitted to SAEPF for further endorsement. These documents are under consideration of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic.
In addition, the Project provided technical support for development of a programme and action plans on transition to sustainable development of the ecological and economic system of Issyk-Kul for 2015-2017, which was later integrated to the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan for the implementation of the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017, approved by order of the Plenipotentiary Representative of the Government of the Kyrgyz Republic in Issyk-Kul region dated February 9, 2015 #21 «On approval of the Strategy for Sustainable Development of the Issyk-Kul region for the years of 2015- 2017”.
Biodiversity has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan for respective years.

description.narrative: Area over which territorial land use planning is fully aligned with requirements for regulated resource use stipulated in the management plans of PA buffer zones and corridors

comment.narrative: 0 ha

0 ha
Key land owners and users in the Project site were identified. The new PA area would largely consist of the Ak-Suu rayon state land reserve – 236,871.70 ha, Otradnaya local self-government body (LSGB) – 23,776.3 ha, Teplklyuchenka LSGB – 9,834.5 ha, Kerege-Tash LSGB – 5,768.3 ha, Bory-Bash LSGB – 2,068.5 ha, Oktyabr LSGB – 1,785.0 ha, Ak-Bulun LSGB – 6,532.6 ha, Chelpek LSGB – 4,646.6 ha, Karakol forestry – 34,501.5ha.
Out of 325 785 ha, 4,939.9 ha are covered with forest, 12,744.3 ha occupied by pasture lands, 932.4 ha covered with water bodies, 50 ha of roads, 101,646 ha of glaciers and 205,472.4 ha refer to the other land category (rocks or stones etc.)
It is expected that out of 325,785 ha, 98,896.8 ha of the Khan-Tengri Park territory will be included in its buffer zone where limited traditional economic activities for local communities are allowed.
According to the legislation on land transfer of the Kyrgyz Republic, the “bottom-up” approach is used. Nine key land owners, LSGB agreed to the land transfer at local level. At present, PA establishment documents are being prepared for getting approval at regional and oblast levels.
Taking into account recommendations of the National Academy of Science on establishment of ecological corridors to connect the new Khan-Tengri Park with the existing Sarychat-Eertash Reserve ecological corridors for migratory mammals were mapped and land owners identified.
Local governments, local self-government bodies and local communities have been informed about establishing ecological corridors and its regimes.
The establishment of the ecological corridors will be accomplished after approval of amendments to the Law on PAs of the Kyrgyz Republic and Regulation on Ecological Corridors, which is now under the consideration of the Kyrgyz Republic Parliament and then the Government.
Guidelines on development of PA management Plan prepared by the Project were approved by the order of the SAEPF Director.
Biodiversity conservation has been mainstreamed into the Sustainable Development Strategy of the Issyk-Kul region for 2015-2017 and its Action Plan.

description.narrative: Better management of hunting in buffers and corridors as reflected in percent of trophy hunting that is controlled and monitored

During the reporting period, 100% of trophy hunting was controlled and monitored in the Project site.
0 cases of violation by trophy hunters were recorded.
A rangers’ handbook developed by the Project is under SAEPF approval. After approval, the handbook will be published and distributed to rangers and volunteer inspectors to improve their capacity in nature management.

It is expected that the Project will be able to evaluate or assess the changes in livelihoods of local communities in 2016.

title.narrative: Protect human health and the environment from unintentional releases of POPs and mercury from the unsound disposal of healthcare waste in Kyrgyzstan project
Protect human health from Persistent Organic Pollutants

description.narrative: The objective of the project is to implement and adopt Best Environmental Practices and Best Available Technologies in healthcare facilities throughout the City of Bishkek to improve the management, treatment, and disposal of healthcare waste.
Energy - policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative:
1. Ministry of Health of the Kyrgyz Republic, by its Directive as of July 3, 2015, established an interdepartmental working group responsible for development of the “National HCWM Strategy for 2016-2020”. The working group has developed the national strategy including all different types of medical waste, National Action Plan on HCWM for 2016-2020 according to the standards and degrees pertaining to HCWM. On December 3, 2015, the last regular working group meeting in 2015, National HCWM Strategy, National Action Plan and National HCWM Strategy's Budget have been presented. Relevant documentation is now under development to take into account recommendations of the working group meeting.
In 2015, two Regulatory Impact Analysis on unintended POPs releases and mercury-containing medical equipment and a matrix indicating possible regulatory gaps and needs in the field of HCWM with a focus on unintended POPs releases and mercury-containing medical devices were developed and put on a public debate on a website of SAEPF: <http://nature.gov.kg/index.php/discussions/901-proekty-obzorov.html>. RIA and a matrix are submitted to the government for further approval process.
2. A database with the definition of equipment needs and best environmental practices was developed. The Ministry of Health by its Order №243 as of May 14, 2015 "On improvement of medical waste management in health care facilities in Bishkek", selected and approved 10 pilot hospitals. The process for the procurement of necessary equipment is launched.
Pilot zones per category (hub, satellite, single source) are identified. Development of an interactive map with HCFs in Bishkek is under progress.
3. Mercury management and phase-out plans for 10 pilot HCFs in Bishkek were developed. The plans were amended and supplemented based on the recommendation from the working meeting with the directors and personnel of these 10 pilot HCFs. Upon finalization, Plans were incorporated into the pilot HCFs regulatory fram

description.narrative: Widening Access to Justice for Legal Empowerment in the Kyrgyz Republic
Justice, Law and Order - policy, planning and administration

1. Number of Universal Periodic Review (UPR) recommendations relevant to the project implemented; 2. Free Legal Aid framework in line with international standards; 3. Rate of formal and informal justice institutions representatives' average knowledge in the area of law (in pilot project regions) 4. Rate on accessibility to formal justice institutions by project target groups' representatives ; Increase in the rate of accessibility to informal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives (in pilot project regions) 5. % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) rating quality of FLA as fully satisfactory (in pilot project regions) 6. % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) who are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. % of the project target groups representatives who have passports, birth and marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

comment.narrative: 1. 11 out of 36 relevant to the project Universal Pediodic Review recommendations implemented by Kyrgyzstan: general recommendations - 7 out of 9; women's rights - 2 out of 12; children's rights - 2 out of 7; People with Disabilities (PwD) - 0 out of 8 2. Free Legal Aid framework (FLA) focused only on criminal cases and do not comply with international standards 3. Formal justice institutions representatives in pilot project regions rated their average knowledge in the area of law as 3,82 out of 5; informal justice institutions representatives in pilot project regions rated their average knowledge in the area of law as 3,39 out of 4. 4. Project target groups representatives in pilot project regions rated accessibility to formal justice institutions as 2,77 out of 5; Project target groups representatives in pilot project regions rated accessibility to informal justice institutions as 2,54 out of 5 5. 17,8% of women; 14,4% of youth and 25,6% of PwDs in pilot project regions rated quality of FLA as fully satisfactory 6. 41,62% of women, 36,50% of youth and 62,82 % of PwDs are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. 92,22% of the project target groups representatives have passports, 97,58% have birth certificates and 46,73% have marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

1. 12 out of 36 Universal Periodic Review recommendations relevant to the project implemented; 2. Draft FLA law includes access to FLA for the victims of crimes that is in line with international standards; 3. 3 % increase in the rate of formal and informal justice institutions representatives' average knowledge in the area of law (in pilot project regions); 4. 3 % increase in the rate of accessibility to formal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives; 10% increase in the rate of accessibility to informal justice institutions by the project target groups' representatives (in pilot project regions) 5. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) rating quality of FLA as fully satisfactory (in pilot project regions) 6. 3 % increase in % of women, youth (boys and girls) and PwDs (men and women) who are aware of their rights and duties (in pilot project regions) 7. 1.7 % increase in % of project target groups representatives, who have passports, birth and marriage certificates (in pilot project regions)

1. 7 UPR recommendations relevant to the project implemented: in particular, 5.31; 5.32; 5.59; 5.100; 7.3; 7.5; 7.6. 2. Draft law on Free Legal Aid includes access to FLA for the victims of crimes and civil cases (effective as of the year 2017). The draft law is submitted to the Parliament and adopted in the 1st reading on 26 June 2015. 3. Analysis of training modules on the rights of vulnerable groups is completed with recommendations for the development of the new module for formal and informal justice institutions and state bodies. Training module is to be developed and trainings provided in the year 2016. 4. Project supported opening of the Ministry of Justice 5 FLA centers (3 in Chui and 2 in Osh provinces). For the last 9 months 13 636 legal consultations were provided by these centers. 4 court buildings (1 in Bishkek city, 1 in Osh city and 2 in Kara-Suu and Nookat districts of Osh province) were made accessible: ramps were constructed, entrances to the meeting halls and reception area were widened. 24 sign-language interpreters were trained on legal issues to provide support to the deaf mutes. 5. Legal clinic has provided 93 consultations and assisted in preparation of 30 legal documents. Central database of the Ministry of Justice is transferred to Open Data format and available in the mobile application.
6.4 centers on legal empowerment were opened in pilot provinces (2 in Chui and 2 in Osh). Database of people in need of legal aid was compiled by the local lawyers and 521 consultations provided during the 4 months period. 243 people received free legal aid by the lawyer of the Ministry of Justice in team of the State Registration Service’s (SRS) mobile group.
7. State Registry System mobile groups issued documents to 150 persons in the project’s pilot Ayil Aymaks starting from September 2015. 10 automated informational systems with protected channel for documentation of the population were installed in pilot provinces. Business processes for 7 servi

description.narrative: The principal objective of the project is to improve well-being of inhabitants of the targeted populated areas affected by uranium, non-ferrous and complex ore mining via creation of an enabling environment for sustainable development of human potential
policy, planning and administration

comment.narrative: 1. Number of poor households. 2. Number of SMEs is low (tbd) due to inadequate diversification of economic activities, resulting from lack of knowledge, non-advanced technologies, means of production and equipment 3. Poor social infrastructure in the village (water supply system, electro supply system, social facilities and etc.); 4. Low capacity of local government representatives and pilot communities to identify and solve internal socio-economic issues. Indicators:

1. Income of 45 households is increased through employment of their members at 8 small enterprises established with UNDP support. 20 households increased their income through a possibility to store and process their harvested fruits and vegetables at 2 small enterprises established with UNDP support. In total, 65 households increased their income 2. 45 jobs (17 for men and 28 for women) are created at 8 small enterprises established with UNDP support 3. 7556 people benefit from improved access to rural infrastructure in 4 target communities, where water supply systems, education and health care facilities are rehabilitated, and conditions of streets are improved 4. 15 staff members of local self-governments from target communities improved their skills on developing and implementing social projects. 7 staff members of local self-governments developed their skills on procurement of goods and services in compliance with national legislation.

1. Not less than in 50 households income is increased through small enterprises 2. 15 small enterprises directed to the economic diversification are created and equipped with new facilities 3. Not less than 10 000 people (40% are women) received improved access to rural infrastructure 4. Not less than 20 local government officials improved their skills on delivering public services 5. National and local governments supported by appropriate toolkits & consultancy to strengthen their capacity in integrated DRR for further scaling up of best practices

title.narrative: Women as Peaceful Voters & Women as Candidates

description.narrative: Women in selected areas exercise their electoral rights and participate in voting and are empowered to run as candidates during local elections

title.narrative: Women as peacful voters amd woment as candidates

description.narrative: The project aims at increasing women’s participation, including from minorities and youth groups, at elections, both as candidates and peaceful voters, in priority geographic areas under currently ongoing PRF projects.
Elections - elections

1)Outcome Indicator 1 a: % of women (disaggregated by age and ethnicity, if possible) in target LSGs voting in elections (compared with previous elections). 2)Output Indicator 1.1.1: % of residents of voting age (disaggregated by age, sex and ethnicity, if possible) are saying they know their electoral rights and exercise them without fear. 3)Outcome Indicator 2 a: Women and men in selected areas, especially youth, have enhanced their knowledge and skills on participating in electoral debates and promoting peaceful elections. 4)Output Indicator 2.1.1 Rating of parties by ‘gender rating’ study provided by women NGOs. 5)Output Indicator 2.2.1 Extent to which media (traditional and new) covers political participations issues, including those related to gender equality. 6)Outcome Indicator 1 a: Number of women-candidates and number of women-council deputies (age and ethnicity disaggregated) at local elections in target geographic areas. 7)Output Indicator 3.1.1: # of women-candidates (age and ethnicity disaggregated) in target communities and supported by the project running for local elections.

comment.narrative: 1)Baseline for Outcome indicator 1: Data on the first case (rural, Northern community): -69.2% women participated in previous municipal (41.8%) and parliament (27.5%) elections. Disaggregated by age and ethnicity at last municipal elections: Age: 60% -18-30, 41.9%-31-40, 52% - 41-60; Ethnic groups: 60% -Kyrgyz ethnic group (migrants from other countries), 45.5% - Kyrgyz, 15.8% - other ethnic groups. Data on the second case (urban, Southern community): -87.8% participated at previous municipal (60.3%) and parliament (22.4%) elections. Disaggregated by age and ethnicity at last municipal elections: Age: 73.3% -18-30, 79.3%-31-40, 54.4% - 41-60, 50% - 61 and up. Whereas at parliament elections they are less active: Age: 20% -18-30, 17.2%-31-40, 28.1% - 41-60, 20% - 61 and up. Ethnic groups (municipal elections): 66.7% Kyrgyz, 51.7% - other ethnic groups; Ethnic groups (parliament elections): 22.2% Kyrgyz, 27.6% - other ethnic groups. 2) Baseline for Output Indicator 1.1.1: Data on the first case (Rural, Northern community): -80,2% of women exercised their electoral rights based on their own choice and will – independently. -Results were segregated by Age: 76% -18-30, 85.7%-31-40, 77.4%-41-60; Ethnicity: ethnic kyrgyz (migrants) - 75%, local Kyrgyz - 79.2%, other ethnic groups - 93.3%. Data on the second case (Urban, Southern community): -81.9% of women exercise their electoral rights independently. -Results were disaggregated by Age: 81.3% -18-30, 78.6%-31-40, 26.4%-41-60, 61 and up – 11.6%; Ethnicity: Kyrgyz – 86.9%, other ethnic groups - 75%. 3) Baseline for Outcome Indicator 2 a: Data on the first case (rural, northern community): - 13,6% of respondents have confirmed their ability and knowledge to promote democratic changes for the communities in peaceful manners Data on the second case (urban, southern community): - 28,2% of respondents have confirmed their ability and knowledge to promote democratic changes for the communities in peaceful manners 4) Ba

1)Target Outcome 1: Not less than previous participation of women who have relevant access to voting during parliament and local elections. 2)Target Output Indicator 1.1.1: The number of voters who are empowered to exercise electoral rights without fear is not less than in the previous elections, taking into account the introduction of new voting regulations 3)Target for Outcome Indicator 2 a: Not less than 50% of respondents: women, men and youth confirm that they have received knowledge and skills to participate in electoral debates and promote peaceful elections 4)Target for Output Indicator 2.1.1: Develop and test methodology of gender rating system of political parties. 1 gender rating results are published and disseminated. 5)Target for Indicator 2.2.1: Media released specific materials on women’s political participation prior to Parliament and local elections. A targeted media campaign on women’s and youth’s participation in elections developed 6)Target for Outcome Indicator 1 a: NA (local elections will take place in 2016) 7)Target for Indicator 3.1.1: NA (local elections will take place in 2016)

Target Outcome 1 result: to ensure women’s wide participation in the elections, the project has engaged 11 local women’s and youth NGOs, who developed the national raising awareness interventions on their active participation in elections. Several knowledge management and advocacy materials were released for a wide-range of target audiences. Formal and informal meetings with the public were conducted, covering around 40, 000 people. A TV series was released to create a positive image of women deputies and women on decision- making positions. The Central Election Committee was supported in releasing the Public Service Announcements(PSAs) that called women for active and self-paced participation in the Parliamentary elections. Target Output Indicator 1.1.1: given that the implementing partners involved were capacitated by the project to run innovative and targeted interventions, such as media campaigns, I-talks, debates, flash-mobs, door-to-door visits and other specific activities in attracting and empowering voters to participate in the elections, the number of voters as a result of the elections, was not not less than in the previous elections, taking into account the introduction of new voting regulations 3)Target for Outcome Indicator 2 a: The Project managed to reach out to a critical mass of women and youth from multi-ethnic rural communities often left out during electoral processes to participate in the elections. In this regards, a participatory methodology has been tested in several communities to assess potential conflicts related to the upcoming elections. In addition, this unique methodology allowed local communities to review the potential conflicts and prepare plan of actions in response to possible conflicts. Based on observations and feedback received, the project was acknowledged to be effective in 2 keys areas 1) mitigating the risk of electoral violence 2 ) ensuring the substantive participation of women in taking a lead in resolving th

description.narrative: It is aimed at supporting and accompanying the CEC in conducting of the upcoming electoral cycle where a massive introduction of ICT will be introduced and ensure that the electoral cycle is free, fair and peaceful.

The main goal of the project is to support and accompany the CEC in conduct of the upcoming electoral cycle where a massive introduction of ICT will be introduced and ensure that the electoral cycle is free, fair and peaceful.
Elections - elections

comment.narrative: 1. CEC faced new challenges due to massive introduction of ICT-tools into the citizens registration and identification announced by the Government and President’s appeal for voter registration. 2. Following the on-going electoral cycles the public confidence needs to be restored to meet the high ‘demand’ for democracy and credible participative elections.

The capacity and resource of CEC strengthened to organize elections in conformity with national and international standards. The capacity and resource of CEC strengthened in the area of communication to answer the high expectation for democracy and credibility and face the new challenge of the introduction of highly specialized electronic equipment. Conduct of nationwide information and communication campaign on democratic elections, civic education, and the introduction of ICT. Creation of a peaceful and secure environment conducive to the organization of peaceful elections
To be implemented on milestone basis

title.narrative: Monitoring System and Management of Environment Info

description.narrative: Strengthening of institutional and legal capacities to enable improvement of the national monitoring system and management of environmental information
To strengthen targeted national capacities to meet Rio Convention objectives through improved procedures and tools to monitor and manage environmental information

comment.narrative: In-depth baseline assessment of current management information system is completed.
Selected updating of technologies for information monitoring and management.

1.1 The synthesis report based on the three (3) in-depth thematic analyses (CBD, CCD, and FCCC) of Kyrgyzstan’s environmental governance are prepared and endorsed by the technical working groups with gender balance number of participants 1.2а Report on information and knowledge needs assessment finalized and agreed on the Rio Working Group created 1.2b Needs assessment report describes the extent to which gender issues are relevant to information and knowledge to meeting and sustaining global environmental objectives
2.1 Assessment report is drafted, peer reviewed and endorsed by stakeholders at a validation workshop 2.2.Institutional analysis an of the challenges and best practices for managing environmental data and information developed 2.3 In-depth baseline assessment of current management information system is completed 2.4 Training needs assessment report finalized and сcomprehensive training programme drafted 2.5 High value pilot sector development plan identified
3.1 Public awareness campaign developed in cooperation with partner development agencies designed and implementation launched 3.2 Not less than 12 articles on the Rio Conventions that highlight the importance of the Rio Conventions published on the media 3.3 At least one PSA completed for radio and television
